When Akbar Hashemi was born, his father was a rich businessman with a valuable pistachio business.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/2010/04/the-middle-road-of-hashemi-rafsanjani.html |title=The Middle Road of Hashemi Rafsanjani |website=pbs.org |date=2010-04-28 |accessdate=2017-01-26}} Hashemi and his partners also owned [[Islamic Azad University]], worth an estimated USD$20–25 billion.http://www.turquoisepartners.com/iraninvestment/IIM-Jul10.pdf{{cite web|title=Hashemi assets|url=http://www.seratnews.ir/fa/news/10462/%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%8A%D9%8A-%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%B4%D9%85%D9%8A-%D9%88-%D8%B4%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%A7%D9%8A%D8%B4-250-%D9%87%D8%B2%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%85%D9%8A%D9%84%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF-%D8%AA%D9%88%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86|accessdate=12 January 2017|language=Persian}} === Assassination attempts === [[File:Hashemi Rafsanjani after assassination attempt.jpg|thumb|Rafsanjani speaking with the media after the first assassination attempt]] Only months after the revolution, Rafsanjani was shot once in the stomach by gunmen''Hardline Ayatollah Shot in Tehran''. Andrew Whitley. The Financial Times (London, England), Saturday, May 26, 1979; pg. 2; Edition 27,874. from one of the groups vying for power amid the political turmoil. He was not seriously wounded—and neither was his wife, who jumped in front to shield him from the attack. "Great men of history do not die," [[Ruhollah Khomeini|Khomeini]] said in announcing that Rafsanjani had survived. == Books == * ''[[Collection of daily memos of Hashemi Rafsanjani|Memories]]'' * ''The Combat Era'' is the title of his book on the events before the 1979 revolution. His devotion to [[Rouhollah Khomeini]], his sympathy with the national movement including [[Mohammad Mosaddegh]] and [[Mahdi Bazargan]] is seen in this book. In this book, he even shows interest in western democracy.Moslem, Mehdi. Factional politics in post-Khomeini Iran. New York: Syracuse University Press, 2002. 371. {{ISBN|0-8156-2978-8}}. * ''Amir Kabir: the Hero of Fighting against Imperialism'' (1968){{cite journal|url=http://library.sharif.ir/parvan/resource/259449/%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%B1_%D9%8A%D8%A7_%D9%82%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86_%D9%85%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B2%D9%87_%D8%A8%D8%A7_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B9%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1|title=امیرکبیر یا قهرمان مبارزه با استعمار|first=هاشمی رفسنجانی،|last=اکبر.|date=1 January 1346|publisher=|accessdate=9 January 2017}} * ''[[Tafsir Rahnama]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.noormags.com/view/fa/articlepage/6640|script-title=fa:تفسیر راهنما از آغاز تا کنون|author=یزدی،محمد علی|work=noormags.com}} * ''Explicit Letters'' In addition, the full text of his [[Friday Prayer]] sermons and his congress keynote speeches are also published separately.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2011/06/110629_l13_hashemi_memoirs_ganji.shtml|script-title=fa:فارسی - ايران - نگاهی دیگر: خاطرات اکبر هاشمی رفسنجانی و حذف روایت کشتار ۶۷ |publisher=BBC News}} Based on his diary, viewpoints, speeches and interviews, several independent books have been published so far. *Encyclopedia of Quran (Farhang-e- Quran) The book in fact considered as a key to the subjects and concepts of Quran. The book has been written by Hashemi and several other scholars.{{cite book|author=Sayyed Ali Sadat Fakhr|url=http://www.noormags.ir/view/fa/articlepage/338619/%d9%81%d8%b1%d9%87%d9%86%da%af-%d9%82%d8%b1%d8%a2%d9%86-(%da%a9%d9%84%db%8c%d8%af-%d8%b1%d8%a7%d9%87%db%8c%d8%a7%d8%a8%db%8c-%d8%a8%d9%87-%d9%85%d9%88%d8%b6%d9%88%d8%b9%d8%a7%d8%aa-%d9%88-%d9%85%d9%81%d8%a7%d9%87%db%8c%d9%85-%d9%82%d8%b1%d8%a2%d9%86-%da%a9%d8%b1%db%8c%d9%85%d8%8c-%d8%a7%da%a9%d8%a8%d8%b1-%d9%87%d8%a7%d8%b4%d9%85%db%8c-%d8%b1%d9%81%d8%b3%d9%86%d8%ac%d8%a7%d9%86%db%8c)?q=%D8%B9%D9%84%DB%8C%20%D8%A7%DA%A9%D8%A8%D8%B1%20%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%B4%D9%85%DB%8C%20%D8%B1%D9%81%D8%B3%D9%86%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C&score=2086.5774&rownumber=6|title=Encyclopedia of Quran|year=2006|pages=95–97|magazine=AynehPajohesh}} == Analysis == Although he was a close follower of Ayatollah Khomeini and considered as a central elite during Islamic revolution, at the same time he was fan of reconstruction of shattered country after war and according to this fact, he selected his cabinets from western-educated technocrats and social reformers. His cabinet largely was a reformist one. Rafsanjani acquired both the support of Imam Khomeini in one hand and Majlis in other hand. In fact, he tried to transfer the economy towards the free-market system. There was a gap among Rafsanjani and Khatami and reform agenda because of his partnership with those who were conservative. The first face of reformist movements began by Rafsanjani.{{cite book|author=Anoushiravan Enteshami & Mahjoob Zweiri|title=Iran and the rise of Neoconservatives, the politics of Tehran's silent {{infobox person |image = Amadou_Hampâté_Bâ.jpg |birth_date=1900/1901 |birth_place=[[Bandiagara]] |death_date= 15 May 1991 |death_place= [[Abidjan]] }} '''Amadou Hampâté Bâ''' (1900/1901 – 15 May 1991) was a [[Mali]]an writer and [[ethnology|ethnologist]].
==Biography== [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/index.html Amadou Hampâté Bâ] was born to an aristocratic [[Fula people|Fula]] family in [[Bandiagara]], the largest city in [[Dogon people|Dogon]] territory and the capital of the precolonial [[Masina Empire]]. At the time of his birth, the area was known as [[French Sudan]] as part of colonial [[French West Africa]], which was formally established a few years before his birth. After his father's death, he was adopted by his mother's second husband, Tidjani Amadou Ali Thiam of the [[Toucouleur people|Toucouleur]] ethnic group. He first attended the [[Qur'an]]ic school run by [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/cerno_bokar_salif/index.html Tierno Bokar], a dignitary of the [[Tijaniyyah]] brotherhood, then transferred to a [[France|French]] school at Bandiagara, then to one at [[Djenné]]. In 1915, he ran away from school and rejoined his mother at [[Kati]], where he resumed his studies.
In 1921, he turned down entry into the ''école normale'' in [[Gorée]]. As a punishment, the governor appointed him to [[Ouagadougou]] with the role he later described as that of "an essentially precarious and revocable temporary writer". From 1922 to 1932, he held several posts in the colonial administration in [[French Upper Volta|Upper Volta]], now [[Burkina Faso]], and from 1932 to 1942 in [[Bamako]]. In 1933, he took six months' leave to visit [[Tierno Bokar]], his spiritual leader. (See also:[[Sufi studies]])
In 1942, he was appointed to the [[Institut Français d’Afrique Noire]] (IFAN — the French Institute of Black Africa) in [[Dakar]], thanks to the benevolence of [[Théodore Monod]], its director. At IFAN, he made [[ethnology|ethnological]] surveys and collected traditions. For 15 years he devoted himself to research, which would later lead to the publication of his work ''L'Empire peul de Macina'' (''The Fula Empire of Macina''). In 1951, he obtained a [[UNESCO]] grant, enabling him to travel to [[Paris]] and meet with intellectuals from Africanist circles, notably [[Marcel Griaule]].
With Mali's independence in 1960, Bâ founded the Institute of Human Sciences in Bamako, and represented his country at the [[UNESCO]] general conferences. In 1962, he was elected to UNESCO's executive council, and in 1966 he helped establish a unified system for the transcription of African languages.
His term in the executive council ended in 1970, and he devoted the remaining years of his life to research and writing. In 1971, he moved to the [[Marcory]] suburb of [[Abidjan]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]],<ref>{{cite web | last =Hawkins | first =Peter | title =Amadou Hampaté Ba | work =French Literature Companion | publisher =Answers.com | url =http://www.answers.com/topic/amadou-hampate-ba | accessdate =2009-04-02 }}</ref> and worked on classifying the archives of West African oral tradition that he had accumulated throughout his lifetime, as well as writing his memoirs (''Amkoullel l'enfant peul'' and ''Oui mon commandant!'', both published posthumously). He died in Abidjan in 1991.
==Bibliography== * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/ahbDaget/sommaire.html ''L'Empire peul du Macina''] (''The Fula Empire of Macina'', 1955, new edition in 1984) * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/sage/tdm.html ''Vie et enseignement de Tierno Bokar, le sage de Bandiagara''] (''The Life and Education of Tierno Bokar, the Sage of Bandiagara'', 1957, rewritten in 1980) (translated into English and published as ''[[A Spirit of Tolerance: The Inspiring Life of Tierno Bokar]]'', Bloomington, Indiana: [[World Wisdom]], 2008) * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/kaidara-fr/tdm.html ''Kaïdara, récit initiatique peul''] 1969 * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/kaidara-en/contents.html Kaïdara, a Fula initiation tale''] 1988 * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/wangrin/tdm.html ''L'étrange destin du Wangrin''] (''The Strange Destiny of Wangrin'', 1973, Grand prix de littérature d’Afrique noire 1974) * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/koodal-lootori/tdm.html ''L'Éclat de la grande étoile''] (''The Brightness of the Great Star'', 1974) * ''Jésus vu par un musulman'' (''Jesus, as Viewed by a Muslim'', 1976) * ''Petit Bodiel (conte peul) et version en prose de Kaïdara'' (''Little Bodiel (a Fula tale) and a prose version of Kaïdara'', 1977) * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/njeddo-dewal/tdm.html ''Njeddo Dewal, mère de la calamité''] (''Njeddo Dewal, Mother of Calamity'', 1985, Fula fantasy tale) * ''La poignée de poussière, contes et récits du Mali'' (''A Handful of Dust, Malian Stories'', 1987) * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/amkullel/tdm.html ''Amkoullel, l'enfant peul''] (''Amkoullel, the Fula Child'', 1991, the first part of his memoir) * [https://www.webpulaaku.net/defte/ahb/oui-mon-commandant/tdm.html ''Oui mon commandant!''] (''Yes, My Commander'', 1994, the second part of his memoir) were published posthumously

[[Art Carney]] (''Walt Disney's Song Parade from Disneyland''[http://cartoonresearch.com/index.php/walt-disneys-song-parade-from-disneyland-on-golden-records/ "Walt Disney's Song Parade from Disneyland on Golden Records"]. Retrieved 2017-09-26.)

[[Nick Cannon]] (2006 adaptation) | nickname = | alias = Riley, Compair Lapin | species = Coney | gender = Male | homeworld = | occupation = Trickster | family = | significantother = }} [[File:Brer Rabbit dream, 1881.jpg|thumb|200px|Br'er Rabbit's dream, from ''Uncle Remus, His Songs and His Sayings: The Folk-Lore of the Old Plantation'', 1881]] '''Br'er Rabbit''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|r|ɛər}} (Brother Rabbit), also spelled '''Bre'r Rabbit''' or '''Brer Rabbit''' or '''Bruh Rabbit''', is a central figure as [[Uncle Remus]] tells stories of the [[Southern United States]]. Br'er Rabbit is a [[trickster]] who succeeds by his [[wit]]s rather than by brawn, provoking authority figures and bending social [[mores]] as he sees fit. [[The Walt Disney Company]] later adapted this character for its 1946 [[animation|animated]] [[motion picture]] ''[[Song of the South]]''. == Tar-Baby story == In one tale, [[Br'er Fox]] constructs a doll out of a lump of tar and dresses it with some clothes. When Br'er Rabbit comes along he addresses the [[Tar-Baby]] amiably, but receives no response. Br'er Rabbit becomes offended by what he perceives as the Tar-Baby's lack of manners, punches it, and in doing so becomes stuck. The more Br'er Rabbit punches and kicks the tar "baby" out of rage, the more he gets stuck. When Br'er Fox reveals himself, the helpless but cunning Br'er Rabbit pleads, "please, Br'er Fox, don't fling me in dat brier-patch," prompting Fox to do exactly that. As rabbits are at home in thickets, the resourceful Br'er Rabbit uses the thorns and briers to escape. The story was originally published in ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' by [[Robert Roosevelt]]; years later [[Joel Chandler Harris]] included his version of the tale in his [[Uncle Remus]] stories. == African origins == [[File:Smit.Lepus crawshayi.jpg|thumb|The [[African savanna hare]] (''Lepus microtis'') found all over [[sub-Saharan Africa]]: the original Br'er Rabbit.]] The Br'er Rabbit stories can be traced back to [[trickster]] figures in Africa, particularly the [[African savanna hare|hare]] that figures prominently in the storytelling traditions in [[West Africa|West]], [[Central Africa|Central]], and [[Southern Africa]]. These tales continue to be part of the traditional folklore of numerous peoples throughout those regions. In the [[Akan people|Akan tradition]]s of West Africa, the trickster is usually the spider [[Anansi]], though the plots in his tales are often identical with those of stories of Br'er Rabbit.{{cite web |first=Joseph A. |last=Opala |authorlink=Joseph Opala |date= |title=Gullah Customs and Traditions |url=http://www.yale.edu/glc/gullah/05.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060517040916/http://www.yale.edu/glc/gullah/05.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-05-17 |work=The Gullah: Rice, Slavery, and the Sierra Leone-American Connection }}{{self-published inline|date=December 2010}} However, Anansi does encounter a tricky rabbit called "Adanko" (Asante-Twi to mean "Hare") in some stories. The Jamaican character with the same name "Brer Rabbit", is an adaptation of the Ananse stories of the Akan people.{{cite web|url=http://anansistories.com/African_Ja_Charact.html|title=African_Ja_Charact|author=|date=|website=anansistories.com|accessdate=23 March 2018}} Some scholars have suggested that in his American incarnation, Br'er Rabbit represented the [[slavery|enslaved]] Africans who used their wits to overcome adversity and to exact revenge on their adversaries, the white slave owners.{{cite book |last=Levine |first=Lawrence |title=Black Culture and Black Consciousness: Afro-American Folk Thought from Slavery to Freedom |year=1977 |publisher=Oxford University Press}} Though not always successful, the efforts of Br'er Rabbit made him a folk hero. However, the trickster is a multidimensional character. While he can be a hero, his amoral nature and his lack of any positive restraint can make him into a villain as well.{{cite book |last=Arnold |first=Albert |title=Monsters, Tricksters, and Sacred Cows: Animal Tales and American Identities |year=1996 |publisher=University of Virginia Press}} For both Africans and African Americans, the animal trickster represents an extreme form of behavior that people may be forced to adopt in extreme circumstances in order to survive. The trickster is not to be admired in every situation. He is an example of what to do, but also an example of what not to do. The trickster's behavior can be summed up in the common African proverb: "It's trouble that makes the monkey chew on [[hot pepper]]s." In other words, sometimes people must use extreme measures in extreme circumstances.{{cite web |url=http://www.authorsden.com/visit/viewarticle.asp?id=1030 |title=Brer Rabbit and Ananse Stories from Africa (article) by Peter E Adotey Addo on AuthorsDen |publisher=Authorsden.com |accessdate=July 3, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Several elements in the Brer Rabbit Tar Baby story (e.g., rabbit needing to be taught a lesson, punches and head butting the rabbit does, the stuck rabbit being swung around and around) are reminiscent of those found in a Zimbabwe-Botswana folktale.{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Alexander McCall |title=The Girl Who Married A Lion and Other Tales from Africa |year=1989 |publisher=Pantheon Books, NY |pages=185–89}} Folklorists in the late 19th century first documented evidence that the American versions of the stories originated among enslaved West Africans based on connections between Br'er Rabbit and ''Leuk'', a rabbit trickster in [[Senegalese]] folklore.{{cite book |last=M'Baye |first=Babacar |title=The Trickster Comes West: Pan-African Influence in Early Black Diasporan Narratives |year=2009 |publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi}} The stories of Br'er Rabbit were written down by [[Robert Roosevelt]], an uncle of US President [[Theodore Roosevelt]]. Theodore Roosevelt wrote in his autobiography about his aunt from the [[State of Georgia]], that "She knew all the 'Br'er Rabbit' stories, and I was brought up on them. One of my uncles, Robert Roosevelt, was much struck with them, and took them down from her dictation, publishing them in ''[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]]'', where they fell flat. This was a good many years before a genius arose who, in 'Uncle Remus', made the stories immortal." These stories were popularized for the mainstream audience in the late 19th century by [[Joel Chandler Harris]] (1845–1908), who wrote down and published many such stories that had been passed down by oral tradition. Harris also attributed the birth name ''Riley'' to Br'er Rabbit. Harris heard these tales in Georgia. Very similar versions of the same stories were recorded independently at the same time by the folklorist [[Alcée Fortier]] in southern [[Louisiana]], where the Rabbit character was known as ''Compair Lapin'' in [[Louisiana Creole|Creole]]. [[Enid Blyton]], the English writer of children's fiction, retold the stories for children. == Cherokee origins == Although [[Joel Chandler Harris]] collected materials for his famous series of books featuring the character Br'er Rabbit in the 1870s, the Br'er Rabbit cycle had been recorded earlier among the [[Cherokee]]s: The "[[tar baby]]" story was printed in an 1845 edition of the ''Cherokee Advocate'', the same year Joel Chandler Harris was born.{{cite web |url=http://www.powersource.com/cocinc/featured/tales.htm |title=Cherokee Tales and Disney Films Explored |publisher=Powersource.com |date=June 15, 1996 |accessdate=July 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524063615/http://www.powersource.com/cocinc/featured/tales.htm |archivedate=May 24, 2011 |df= }} Rabbit and Hare myths abound among Algonquin Indians in Eastern North America, particularly under the name [[Nanabozho]]. The Great Hare is generally worshipped among tribes in eastern Canada. In "That the People Might Live: Native American Literatures and Native American Community" by Jace Weaver, the origins of Br'er Rabbit and other literature are discussed. To say that a story only originates from one culture and not another can only be true when a group of people exist in complete isolation from others. Although the Cherokee had lived in isolation from Europeans in the remote past, a substantial amount of interaction was to occur among North American tribes, Europeans, and those from the enslaved population during the 18th and 19th centuries. It is impossible to ascertain whether the Cherokee story independently predated the African American story. In a Cherokee tale about the briar patch, "the fox and the wolf throw the trickster rabbit into a thicket from which the rabbit quickly escapes."{{cite journal|year=1990|journal=Latin American Indian literatures journal|publisher=Dept. of Foreign Languages at Geneva College|volume=6|page=10}} There was a "melding of the Cherokee rabbit-trickster ... into the culture of African slaves."[https://books.google.com/books?id=08SkJw26qoMC&pg=PA4&lpg=PA4&dq=%22brer+rabbit%22+cherokee&source=web&ots=RMF5bsVquT&sig=jAm12HBXucpKmOoPhka2WcphA3M#PPA3,M1 ''That the People Might Live: Native American Literatures and Native American Community''], p. 4 == In popular culture == [[File:Eatonton ga-brer rabbit-2.jpg|thumb|150px|right|[[Eatonton, GA|Eatonton, Georgia]]'s statue of Br'er Rabbit]] ===Under Disney=== [[File:Brer Rabbit Disney screenshot.png|200px|thumb|left|Br'er Rabbit in Disney's ''[[Song of the South]]'' (1946). Disney's version of the character is drawn in a more humorous and lovable style than the illustrations of Br'er Rabbit in Harris' books.]] *The 1946 [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] film ''[[Song of the South]]'' is a [[frame story]] based on two Br'er Rabbit stories, "[[The Laughing Place]]" and "[[The Tar Baby]]". The character of Br'er Rabbit was voiced by [[Johnny Lee (actor)|Johnny Lee]] in the film, and was portrayed as more of a "lovable trickster" than previous tales.Brasch, Walter M. (2000). ''Brer Rabbit, Uncle Remus, and the 'Cornfield Journalist': The Tale of Joel Chandler Harris''. Mercer University Press. pp. 74, 275. Disney comics starring that version of Br'er Rabbit have been produced since 1946.{{cite web|url=http://coa.inducks.org/character.php?c=BR&c1=date|title=Brer Rabbit - I.N.D.U.C.K.S.|author=|date=|website=coa.inducks.org|accessdate=23 March 2018}} *[[Splash Mountain]], a thrill ride at [[Magic Kingdom]], [[Disneyland]], and [[Disneyland Tokyo]], is based on the above 1946 film's animated segments featuring Br'er Rabbit. Br'er Rabbit also appears at the [[Walt Disney Parks and Resorts]] for meet-and-greets, parades and shows. He also has a cameo appearance in ''[[Who Framed Roger Rabbit]]'', and appears as one of the guests in ''[[House of Mouse]]''. He also appears in the film ''[[Mickey's Magical Christmas: Snowed in at the House of Mouse]]'', often seen hopping in the applauding crowd, as well as in the video game ''[[Kinect Disneyland Adventures]]''. Starting with the first Splash Mountain Disney park attraction in 1989, [[Jess Harnell]] has provided the voice acting for Br'er Rabbit in all his modern Disney appearances since. *An ''Uncle Remus and His Tales of Br'er Rabbit'' newspaper strip ran from October 14, 1946 through December 31, 1972.[http://cartoonician.com/disneys-uncle-remus-strips/ "Disney’s “Uncle Remus” strips," ''Hogan's Alley'' #16, 2009] ===Non-Disney=== * The ''[[Uncle Remus]] and His Tales of Br'er Rabbit'' newspaper strip ([[King Features Syndicate]]) ran from October 14, 1945, through December 31, 1972.{{cite news|url=http://cartoonician.com/disneys-uncle-remus-strips/ |title=Disney’s "Uncle Remus" strips|work=Hogan's Alley|number=16|date= 2009}} *On April 21, 1972, astronaut [[John Young (astronaut)|John Young]] became the [[List of Apollo astronauts#Apollo astronauts who walked on the Moon|ninth person]] to step onto the Moon, and in his first words he stated, "I'm sure glad they got ol' Brer Rabbit, here, back in the briar patch where he belongs."{{cite web |title=Back in the Briar Patch |url=http://www.hq.nasa.gov/alsj/a16/a16.eva1prelim.html |publisher=Apollo Lunar Surface Journal |accessdate=November 27, 2011}} *In 1975, the stories were retold for an adult audience in the cult animation film ''[[Coonskin (film)|Coonskin]]'', directed by [[Ralph Bakshi]]. *In 1984, American composer [[Van Dyke Parks]] produced a children's album, ''[[Jump! (album)|Jump!]]'', based on the Brer Rabbit Tales. *1998's ''[[Star Trek: Insurrection]]'' saw the ''[[USS Enterprise (NCC-1701-E)|Starship Enterprise]]'' enter a region of space called the ''Briar Patch''. At some point during a battle with the Son'a, [[William Riker|Commander Riker]] states that it is "time to use the Briar Patch the way Br'er Rabbit did". *A direct-to-video film based on the stories, ''[[The Adventures of Brer Rabbit]]'', was released in 2006. *There is a brand of molasses named after the character that is currently produced by B&G Foods. https://www.bgfoods.com/brands/brer-rabbit == See also == * [[Gullah language#Gullah storytelling|Gullah Storytelling]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.wrensnest.org/ The Wrens Nest 100 Years OF Telling Tales] {{Wikisource|Uncle Remus: His Songs and His Sayings|Uncle Remus’ Br'er Rabbit stories}} {{Commons category|Br'er Rabbit}} * Full text of [http://www.gutenberg.org/browse/authors/h#a868 Joel Chandler Harris] from [[Project Gutenberg]] * [http://www.americanfolklore.net/brer-rabbit.html Brer Rabbit Stories at AmericanFolklore.net] * [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/oldsayville/brer.htm&date=2009-10-25+23:59:00 Robert Roosevelt's Brer Rabbit stories] * [http://www.bartleby.com/55/1.html Theodore Roosevelt autobiography on Brer Rabbit and his Uncle] * [http://coa.inducks.org/simp.php?lg=0&d1=br&pagel=l Inducks' index of Disney comic stories featuring Br'er Rabbit] * [https://archive.org/details/BrotherRabbitAndTarBaby Archived audio recording of an educational ArtsSmarts elementary school recording of "Brother Rabbit and Tar Baby"] {{American tall tales}} {{Uncle Remus}} [[Category:Fictional hares and rabbits]] [[Category:Georgia folklore]] [[Category:Song of the South characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1881]] [[Category:Characters in American novels of the 19th century]] [[Category:African-American cultural history]] [[Category:Fictional tricksters]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} The '''Brat Pack''' is a nickname given to a group of young actors who frequently appeared together in teen-oriented [[:Category:Coming-of-age films|coming-of-age films]] in the 1980s. First mentioned in a 1985 [[New York (magazine)|''New York'']] magazine article, it is now usually defined as the cast members of two specific films released in 1985—''[[The Breakfast Club]]'' and ''[[St. Elmo's Fire (film)|St. Elmo's Fire]]''—although other actors are sometimes included. The "core" members are considered to be [[Emilio Estevez]], [[Anthony Michael Hall]], [[Rob Lowe]], [[Andrew McCarthy]], [[Demi Moore]], [[Judd Nelson]], [[Molly Ringwald]], and [[Ally Sheedy]]. ==Membership== The term "Brat Pack", a play on the [[Rat Pack]] from the 1950s and 1960s, was first popularized in a 1985 ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine cover story, which described a group of highly successful film stars in their early twenties.{{cite journal |url=http://nymag.com/movies/features/49902/ | last=Blum |first=David |authorlink=David Blum |date=June 10, 1985|title=Hollywood's Brat Pack |journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |volume= |issue= |pages=40–47}} [[David Blum]] wrote the article after witnessing several young actors (Emilio Estevez, Rob Lowe, and Judd Nelson) being mobbed by groupies at Los Angeles' [[Hard Rock Cafe]].Mansour, David. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=hK0rPUF85loC&printsec=frontcover From Abba to Zoom: A Pop Culture Encyclopedia of the Late 20th Century]'' (Andrews McMeel Publishing, 2005), p. 56. The group has been characterized by the partying of members such as [[Robert Downey Jr.]], Estevez, Lowe, and Nelson.{{cite news |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |author2=Steven Paul Davies |date=December 15, 2000 |title=The year of the brat |journal=[[The Guardian]]|url=http://film.guardian.co.uk/features/featurepages/0,,411528,00.html |accessdate= 2008-03-19}} However, an appearance in one or both of the ensemble casts of [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]]' ''The Breakfast Club'' and [[Joel Schumacher]]'s ''St. Elmo's Fire'' is often considered the prerequisite for being a core Brat Pack member.{{cite news |last=Fine |first=Marshall |title=Remember the Brat Pack? Well, Now That They're Grown Up... |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 24, 1993 |page=20 }}{{cite book|title=Brat Pack: Confidential |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |author2=Steven Paul Davies |year=2000 |publisher=B T Batsford |url=http://www.bratpackconfidential.com |isbn=978-0-7134-8685-8 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219235500/http://www.bratpackconfidential.com/ |archivedate=February 19, 2008 }}{{cite news |last=Eaton |first=Andrew |title=For a short time they were on fire, then they vanished into obscurity. Whatever happened to the Brat Pack of the 1980s? |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-13099506.html |publisher=''[[The Scotsman]]'' |date=January 20, 2007 |accessdate=2008-03-28 |newspaper=The Scotsman }} With this criterion, the most commonly cited members include:{{cite web |url=http://www.thebratpacksite.com |title=The Brat Pack Site|publisher=The Brat Pack Site|accessdate=2008-03-18 |last=Currie |first=Jamie |year=2003 }}{{cite episode|series=The E! True Hollywood Story|serieslink=The E! True Hollywood Story|title=The Brat Pack |accessdate=2008-03-18}}{{cite web |url=http://www.teenfi.com/movies/bratpack-5780.html |title=What Happened to the Brat Pack? |author=Earnshaw, Helen |publisher=''Teen First'' |date=July 18, 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-15}} * [[Emilio Estevez]] * [[Anthony Michael Hall]] * [[Rob Lowe]] * [[Andrew McCarthy]] * [[Demi Moore]] * [[Judd Nelson]] * [[Molly Ringwald]] * [[Ally Sheedy]] Absent from most lists is [[Mare Winningham]], the only principal member of either cast who never starred in any other films with any other cast members.{{cite web|url=http://www.bratpackconfidential.com/brat-pack.html |title=Brat Pack Confidential: The Players |publisher=Brat Pack Confidential|accessdate=2008-03-19 |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |author2=Davies, Steven Paul|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409133511/http://www.bratpackconfidential.com/brat-pack.html|archivedate=April 9, 2008}} Estevez was cited as the "unofficial president" of the Brat Pack. He and Demi Moore were once engaged. In 1999, McCarthy said he was never a member of the group: "The media made up this sort of tribe. I don't think I've seen any of these people since we finished ''St. Elmo's Fire''."Miller, Samantha and Jewel, Dan. [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20127981,00.html "Brat Race"]. ''People''. April 19, 1999. The initial ''New York'' article covered a group of actors larger, or more inclusive, than the currently understood meaning of the term "Brat Pack". For example, most of the cast members of ''[[The Outsiders (film)|The Outsiders]]'' were mentioned, including [[Tom Cruise]], [[C. Thomas Howell]], [[Matt Dillon]], [[Patrick Swayze]], and [[Ralph Macchio]], none of whom starred in any other 1980s movies with any "core" Brat Packers, besides [[Patrick Swayze]]. [[Charlie Sheen]] appears in several lists – more for his family relationship to Brat Pack leader Emilio Estevez and his partying than for his collaborative film work with other members. [[James Spader]] and [[Robert Downey, Jr.]] have also been considered members, and performed alongside other Brat Packers: both of them with Andrew McCarthy in ''[[Less Than Zero (film)|Less Than Zero]]''; Spader with McCarthy in ''[[Mannequin (1987 film)|Mannequin]]'' and with McCarthy and Molly Ringwald in ''[[Pretty in Pink]]''; and Downey with Anthony Michael Hall (''[[Weird Science (film)|Weird Science]]'' and ''[[Johnny Be Good]]''; and the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'') and with Molly Ringwald (''[[The Pick-up Artist (film)|The Pick-up Artist]]''). Other actors who have been linked with the group include [[Kevin Bacon]], [[Matthew Broderick]], [[Jon Cryer]], [[John Cusack]], [[Jami Gertz]], [[Mary Stuart Masterson]], [[Sean Penn]], [[Kiefer Sutherland]], and [[Lea Thompson]]. In her autobiography, [[Melissa Gilbert]] connects herself with the Brat Pack, as her social life centered on Estevez and Lowe (both of whom she was engaged to). Through frequent collaborative work, the actor [[Harry Dean Stanton]], then in his late 50s, became a mentor for the group of young actors. ==Article== David Blum's ''New York'' story, titled "Hollywood's Brat Pack", ran on June 10, 1985. It was originally supposed to be just about Emilio Estevez, but one night, Estevez invited Blum to hang out with him, Rob Lowe, Judd Nelson, and others at the Hard Rock Cafe. It was a typical night out for the group, who had gotten close while filming ''St. Elmo's Fire''. That night, Blum decided to change the article's focus to an entire group of young actors at the time. The ''St. Elmo's Fire'' crew members did not like Blum and sensed that he was jealous of the actors' success.Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried: The Brat Pack, John Hughes, And Their Impact on a Generation''. Three Rivers Press. pp. 106–119. When the piece ran, the actors all felt betrayed, especially Estevez. The article mentioned people in several films but focused on Estevez, Lowe, and Nelson, and portrayed those three negatively. The "Brat Pack" label, which the actors disliked, stuck for years afterward.{{Cite web|url=http://observer.com/1999/08/actor-andrew-mccarthy-is-bitter-about-brat-pack-past/|title=Actor Andrew McCarthy Is Bitter About Brat Pack Past|date=August 30, 1999|website=Observer|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-23}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Reason-Judd-Nelson-Hated-Brat-Pack-Label-86667.html|title=The Reason Judd Nelson Hated The Brat Pack Label|date=October 6, 2015|website=Cinemablend.com|access-date=2016-05-23}} Before the article ran, they had been regarded as talented individuals; after the article, all of them were grouped together and regarded as unprofessional. Interviewed for Susannah Gora's 2010 book ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried: The Brat Pack, John Hughes, And Their Impact on a Generation'', Blum admitted that he should not have written the article.Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried''. Three Rivers Press. pp. 117–128, 289–291, 336. With the increased negative attention to them, the actors soon stopped socializing with one another. On the group's camaraderie, Ally Sheedy later said, "[The article] just destroyed it. I had felt truly a part of something, and that guy just blew it to pieces."Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried''. Three Rivers Press. p. 128. ==Legacy== During the late 1980s, several of the Brat Pack actors had their careers mildly derailed by problems relating to drugs, alcohol, and in Lowe's case, a sex tape. According to Gora, "Many believe they could have gone on to more serious roles if not for that article. They were talented. But they had professional difficulties, personal difficulties after that."Wilson, Craig. [https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/news/2010-02-08-bratpack08_ST_N.htm "John Hughes and the Brat Pack, revisited"]. ''usatoday.com''. February 16, 2010. Retrieved 2011-01-24. By the 21st century, the term "Brat Pack" had lost its negative connotation.Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried''. Three Rivers Press. p. 332. The films themselves have been described as representative of "the socially apathetic, cynical, money-possessed and ideologically barren eighties generation."{{cite web |url=http://eightiesclub.tripod.com/id299.htm |title=13. The Brat Pack |accessdate=2008-03-18 |last=Manning |first=Jason |year=2000 |work=Material Things |publisher=The Eighties Club}}{{cite web|url=http://www.saxonbullock.com/don't%20you%20forget%20about%20me.htm |title=Don't You Forget About Me |author=Bullock, Saxon |publisher=Originally published in DVD Review |date=September 2004 |accessdate=2008-08-15 |quote=...ended up representing both the best and worst of the ambitious, materialistic 'Me' generation. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905165501/http://www.saxonbullock.com/don%27t%20you%20forget%20about%20me.htm |archivedate=September 5, 2008 }} They made frequent use of adolescent [[archetype]]s, were often set in the suburbs surrounding Chicago, and focused on white, middle-class teenage angst.{{cite journal |last=Lurie |first=Karen |title= Brat Pack |journal=St. James Encyclopedia of Popular Culture |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_g1epc/is_bio/ai_2419200128 |year=2002 }}{{cite web|last=Horwitz |first=Laura |title=The Brat Pack: 80's Icons |url=http://www.6degreesfilm.com/features.php?id=79 |accessdate=2008-03-28 |publisher=6 Degrees Film |year=2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208073706/http://www.6degreesfilm.com/features.php?id=79 |archivedate=December 8, 2008 }} According to author Susannah Gora, these films "changed the way many young people looked at everything from class distinction to friendship, from love to sex and fashion to music." They are considered "among the most influential pop cultural contributions of their time."Gora, Susannah. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=XawD2yexM_kC&printsec=frontcover You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried: The Brat Pack, John Hughes, and Their Impact on a Generation]'' (Random House, Inc., 2010), p. 3. In 2012, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' listed ''The Breakfast Club'' as the best high school movie ever made.[http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20483133_20632183_21215570,00.html "50 Best High School Movies"]. ew.com. September 22, 2012. Retrieved March 2, 2013. On [[VH1]]'s list of the 100 greatest teen stars, Molly Ringwald was ranked #1, Rob Lowe was ranked #2, Anthony Michael Hall was ranked #4, Ally Sheedy was ranked #34, and Andrew McCarthy was ranked #40.[https://web.archive.org/web/20060909103649/http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/the_greatest/97838/episode_featured_copy.jhtml "100 Greatest Teen Stars #'s 20-1"]. vh1.com. Retrieved March 2, 2013.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070103155515/http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/the_greatest/97837/episode_featured_copy.jhtml "100 Greatest Teen Stars #'s 40-21"]. vh1.com. Retrieved March 2, 2013. ==Filmography== Beyond the two primary films, there is no generally accepted list of "Brat Pack" movies. Molly Ringwald continued acting in films throughout the 1990s and in 2001, began performing as [[Sally Bowles]] in the Broadway revival of ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]].'' In 2013, she released a jazz record called ''Except Sometimes"''.{{Cite news|url=http://gazettereview.com/2017/01/happened-molly-ringwald-news-updates/|title=What Happened to Molly Ringwald – News & Updates – The Gazette Review|last=Briscoe|first=Jake|date=January 11, 2017|work=The Gazette Review|access-date=2017-05-04|language=en-US}} She also began starring in television shows such as [[The Secret Life of the American Teenager|''The Secret Life of the American Teenage''r]] and [[Riverdale (2017 TV series)|''Riverdale'']]. [[Emilio Estevez]] and [[Judd Nelson]] also continued to act. Nelson has performed on three seasons on the show "[[Suddenly Susan]]" and "[[Bad Kids Go to Hell]]".{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/movies/whatever-happened-to-emilio-estevez-ally-sheedy-molly-ringwald-judd-nelson-and-anthony-michael-hall-from-the-breakfast-club/news-story/30718ac13a55b4a0251579ee4efdc0be|title=Whatever happened to the Breakfast Club?|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2017-05-04|language=en}} [[Ally Sheedy]] has acted in more independent works and shows like [[Kyle XY]] and also she teaches at [[LaGuardia High School of Performing Arts|La Guardia High school of Performing Arts]]. Close contributor [[Robert Downey Jr.]] became one of the most successful actors since then. His most acclaimed character is [[Iron Man|Tony Stark / Iron Man]] in the 2008 [[Marvel Studios]] film ''[[Iron Man (2008 film)|Iron Man]]'', a role he later reprised in multiple sequels, several {{marriage|Cherry Britton|1984}} (his death) | children = 5; including [[Richard Cant]] }} '''Brian Cant''' (12 July 1933 – 19 June 2017) was an English [[actor]] of stage, television and film, [[television presenter]], voice artist and writer best known for his work in [[BBC]] television programmes for children from 1964 onward, most notably ''[[Play School (UK TV series)|Play School]]''. ==Early life and education== Cant was born in [[Ipswich]] and educated at Northgate Grammar School for Boys, a state grammar school, since renamed [[Northgate High School, Ipswich|Northgate High School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.suffolksociety.org/moderator/uploads/SV%20121%20Spring.pdf|title=Suffolk View|work=The Suffolk Society|date=Spring 2013|accessdate=22 May 2016}} He trained with [[Ipswich Town F.C.]] youth team. He worked as a printer before starting to act in the late 1950s. ==Television and film== Cant was performing in [[BBC Schools]] drama television programmes about the Romans for the corporation when he heard that auditions were being held for a new pre-school children's programme which was to be shown on the new [[BBC 2]] channel. This was ''[[Play School (UK TV series)|Play School]]''. At his audition he was asked by programme creator and the series' first producer [[Joy Whitby]] to get in a cardboard box and pretend to 'row out to sea'.{{cite web|author=Interviews by Sarah Williams |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/oct/15/how-we-made-play-school |title=How we made: Joy Whitby and Phyllida Law on Play School | Culture |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=6 August 2014}} He pretended to fish from his 'boat' and caught a [[wellington boot]] full of custard. He was cast as a presenter and first appeared on the third week in May 1964, and stayed with the programme for 21 of its 24-year run and becoming, according to Whitby, 'Mr Play School'. In an interview, he defended ''Play School'' and similar children's programmes as being designed to encourage children to try out the ideas presented. His involvement in ''Play School'' directly led to his work on three linked [[Gordon Murray (puppeteer)|Gordon Murray]] puppet series: ''[[Camberwick Green]]'' (1966), ''[[Trumpton]]'' (1967), and ''[[Chigley]]'' (1969).{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/jun/20/brian-cant-obituary |title=Brian Cant obituary |last=Jeffries |first=Stuart |access-date=21 June 2017 |work=[[The Guardian]] |publication-date=20 June 2017}} Later he hosted or co-hosted the programmes ''[[Play Away]]'' (1971–84), and ''[[Bric-a-Brac]]'' (1980–82) for slightly older children. From 1990 to 1999, Cant starred as Brian the farmer in the children's television puppet programme ''[[Dappledown Farm]]'', as well as providing the voice for one of the characters, Harry the Heron.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.handsuppuppets.com/html/DappledownFarm.html |title=Dappledown Farm children's TV Series Puppetry information |publisher=Handsuppuppets.com |date= |accessdate=6 August 2014}} Cant was also the storyteller of the UK version of ''[[Jay Jay the Jet Plane]]'', and the narrator for the popular Canadian children's show ''Bruno''.{{Cite web |url=https://www.doyouremember.co.uk/memory/brian-cant |title=Brian Cant |website=Do You Remember?}} Cant also appeared in television series for adults. In the 1960s he appeared in two ''[[Doctor Who]]'' stories, in 1965 as Kert Gantry in ''[[The Daleks' Master Plan]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/daleksmasterplan/detail.shtml#cast |title=Doctor Who Classic Episode Guide – The Daleks' Master Plan – Details |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=6 August 2014}} and in 1968 as Tensa in ''[[The Dominators]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/dominators/detail.shtml#cast |title=Doctor Who Classic Episode Guide – The Dominators – Details |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=6 August 2014}} In 1979 he presented the BBC programme ''[[The Great Egg Race]]'',{{Cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p0146705 |title=The Great Egg Race |website= BBC}} and was one of the guest presenters featured in the 1982 series of the game show ''[[It's a Knockout]]'' after [[Eddie Waring]] retired.{{Cite web |url=http://www.its-a-knockout.tv/bbc.htm |title=It's A Knockout - The BBC Series. |website=It's A Knockout}} In 1998 Cant parodied his previous contributions as a narrator in 'The Organ Gang', a weekly segment in [[Lee and Herring]]'s ''[[This Morning with Richard Not Judy]]'', a BBC TV Sunday afternoon comedy show.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/thismorningwithrichardnotjudy/ |title=Comedy – This Morning With Richard Not Judy |publisher=BBC |date=4 October 2007 |accessdate=6 August 2014}} He also made three appearances in the BBC1 daytime drama ''[[Doctors (2000 TV series)|Doctors]]'', each time as a different character, the last in 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0134454/|title=Brian Cant|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=6 August 2014}} His film appearances were few but included brief roles in ''[[The Pleasure Girls]]'' (1965), ''[[The Sandwich Man (1966 film)|The Sandwich Man]]'' (1966), and ''[[A Feast at Midnight]]'' (1995), starring [[Christopher Lee]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/15359486.Obituary___Brian_Cant__popular_children_s_broadcaster_and_the_voice_of_Trumpton/?ref=arc |title=Obituary - Brian Cant, popular children's broadcaster and the voice of Trumpton |access-date=22 June 2017 |work=HeraldScotland |publication-date=20 June 2017}} In 2001, Cant appeared in a music video on [[Orbital (band)|Orbital]]'s DVD ''[[The Altogether#DVD Version|The Altogether]]''.{{Cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/opinion/obituaries/15359486.Obituary___Brian_Cant__popular_children_s_broadcaster_and_the_voice_of_Trumpton/ |title=Obituary - Brian Cant, popular children's broadcaster and the voice of Trumpton |access-date=23 June 2017 |work=HeraldScotland |publication-date=20 June 2017}} The clip is similar to ''Play School'', featuring Cant in his familiar presenter role.{{cite web|url=http://www.benstock.co.uk/otherfilms.html |title=Jes Benstock – Other Films |publisher=Benstock.co.uk |date= |accessdate=6 August 2014}} He read the second half of [[Ann Jungman]]'s ''Vlad the Drac'' books for audiobook, replacing [[Anthony Daniels]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.audiobooktown.net/vlad-the-drac-vampire-audiobook |title=Free Vlad the Drac Vampire Audiobook read by Brian Cant |website=audiobooktown.net}} He was also the narrator of the UK dub of ''[[Jay Jay the Jet Plane]]''. In April 2007, Cant was named as the best-loved voice from UK children's television, in a poll of over 1,200 people for ''[[Underground Ernie]]'' magazine. Cant came ahead of ''[[Bagpuss]]'' and ''[[Ivor the Engine]]'' narrator [[Oliver Postgate]] in second place, with [[David Jason]] (''[[Danger Mouse (1981 TV series)|Danger Mouse]]'') polling third.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6525593.stm |title=Cant 'best children's TV voice' |publisher=BBC News |date=5 April 2007 |accessdate=6 August 2014}} On 28 November 2010, he received the special award at the [[British Academy Children's Awards|Children's BAFTAs]] for his work in children's television.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11860702|title=Three Children's Baftas for Horrible Histories|date=29 November 2010|work=BBC News|publisher=BC|accessdate=29 November 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11809226|title=Brian Cant to be honoured at children's Baftas|date=22 November 2010|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=24 November 2010}} During his acceptance speech he said, "When I was a child I spake as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child. When I became a man I spake as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child, and they paid me for it...!"{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/brian-cant-remembered-sixties-childrens-tv-presenter-83-play-school-play-away-a7799256.html|title=Brian Cant obituary: Charismatic Sixties children's TV presenter|date=20 June 2017|publisher=independent.co.uk|accessdate=22 June 2017}} ==Theatre== Cant's theatre credits include ''Still Playing Away'',[http://www.bucksfreepress.co.uk/news/649326.brian_goes_back_to_playschool/]''[[The Railway Children]]'', ''[[An Ideal Husband]]'',{{Cite news |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/news/a831163/play-school-play-away-presenter-brian-cant-dies-aged-83/ |title=Play School and Play Away presenter Brian Cant dies, aged 83 |last=Harp |first=Justin |access-date=23 June 2017 |work=Digital Spy |publication-date=19 June 2017}} ''[[Habeas Corpus (play)|Habeas Corpus]]'', ''[[Gaslight (play)|Gaslight]]'', ''[[Side by Side by Sondheim]]'', ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' (in which he memorably ad-libbed a reference to his work on ''[[Play School (UK TV series)|Play School]]''), ''[[Oh, Coward!]]'', ''[[There's No Place Like a Home]]'' and many more, as well as [[pantomime]]s. ==Personal life== Cant lived in [[Chalfont St Giles]], [[Buckinghamshire]]. He was married twice and had five children. He had two sons from his first marriage to Mary Gibson, including the actor [[Richard Cant]]. In 1984, he married writer and director Cherry Britton, sister of TV presenter [[Fern Britton]] and actor [[Jasper Britton]]. They had three children.{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2017/06/19/play-school-presenter-brian-cant-has-died-aged-83/ |title=Play School presenter Brian Cant has died, aged 83 |access-date=23 June 2017 |work=The Telegraph |publication-date=19 June 2017}} In 1999, he was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]], referring to this in an interview with ''[[BBC Breakfast]]'' which was shown on 24 November 2010.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11827013 |title=BBC News – Brian Cant to receive children's Bafta |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2014}} He died on 19 June 2017, at the age of 83, at [[Denville Hall]], in [[Northwood, London]], a retirement home often used by those in the entertainment industry.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-40335213|title=Brian Cant, ''Play School'' presenter, dies at 83|publisher=BBC News|date=19 June 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/story/play-school-presenter-brain-cant-dies-10920663|title=''Play School'' presenter Brian Cant dies|publisher=Sky News|date=19 June 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Brian Cant}} *{{IMDb name|id=0134454|name=Brian Cant}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101129015258/http://www.bafta.org/awards/childrens/brian-cant-to-be-honoured-at-the-2010-ea-british-academy-childrens-awards,1520,BA.html Brian Cant Honoured at the 2010 British Academy Children's Awards] * [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/brian-cant-remembered-sixties-childrens-tv-presenter-83-play-school-play-away-a7799256.html Obituary] in ''[[The Independent]]'' by [[Marcus Williamson]] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cant, Brian}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Children's television presenters]] {{BLP sources|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | Name = Bunny DeBarge | Background = solo_singer |image = | birth_name = Etterlene DeBarge | Alias = Etterlene Jordan
Etterlene Jordan–Knight
Etterlene DeBarge–Knight | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|3|15}} | birth_place = [[Detroit, Michigan]], U.S. | origin = [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]] | Instrument = [[Vocals]] | Occupation = {{hlist|[[Singer-songwriter]]|[[music composer]]|[[record producer]]}} | Genre = {{hlist|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]|[[Soul music|soul]]|[[Gospel music|gospel]]}} | Label = [[Motown Records|Motown]] | years_active = 1979–present | Associated_acts = {{hlist|[[DeBarge]]|[[Switch (band)|Switch]]|[[El DeBarge]]|[[Bobby DeBarge]]}} }} '''Etterlene "Bunny" DeBarge''' (born March 15, 1955) is an [[Americans|American]] [[soul music|soul]] singer–songwriter, best known as the lone female sibling of the Motown [[DeBarge family|family group]] [[DeBarge]]. She is also best known as the lead vocalist behind the classic R&B ballad, "[[A Dream (DeBarge song)|A Dream]]" from the group's ''[[In a Special Way]]'' album and is also the co-writer of the group's 1982 breakthrough hit, "[[I Like It (DeBarge song)|I Like It]]" and the number-one hit, "[[Time Will Reveal (song)|Time Will Reveal]]". ==Life and career== ===Early life=== Etterlene DeBarge was the eldest of ten children, born to [[Etterlene DeBarge|Etterlene (née) Abney]] and Robert DeBarge, Sr. While spending her initial childhood in [[Detroit]], her family moved to [[Grand Rapids, Michigan|Grand Rapids]] when she was sixteen. Bunny would later recall years of [[child abuse|physical and sexual abuse]] at the hands of her father, stating that he had started [[molesting]] her when she was seven and this carried on until she was thirteen. Bunny also detailed troubles in public school where she and her brothers were constantly bullied and taunted by black schoolmates for their [[multiracial]] ethnicity. Bunny found solace in music, singing in her uncle's church as a child. She and her brothers soon participated in several groups together in various times. In 1972, DeBarge dropped out of school and married her first husband, for whom she'd be the mother of two children (they later divorced). Since she wasn't into instruments like her brothers were, Bunny taught herself how to write songs and compose melodies, which later paid off as she got older. ===Music career=== In 1979, after a couple years watching her brothers [[Bobby DeBarge|Bobby]] and Tommy ride to musical stardom as members of the band [[Switch (band)|Switch]], Bunny teamed up with her three brothers [[Randy DeBarge|Randy]], [[Mark DeBarge|Mark]] and [[El DeBarge|El]] and became the DeBarges. They signed with [[Motown Records|Motown]] after their demo tape was passed off by Switch's Gregory Williams to Motown CEO [[Berry Gordy]], who was left impressed by the siblings and soon put the band on a salary. Between 1979 and 1981, Bunny and her brothers worked behind the scenes mainly on the works of Switch, with Bunny in particular collaborating with her brother Bobby on songs such as "Hold On to My Love",{{cite AV media notes |title=Hold On |titlelink= |others=High Inergy|year=1980 |chapter= |url= |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |page= |pages= |type= |publisher=Gordy Records |id= |location=Hollywood, California |ref= }} "Love Over and Over Again" and "My Friend in the Sky". In 1981, Bunny co-produced the DeBarges' [[The DeBarges|self-titled debut album]] and was featured on lead vocals alongside brother El on "Share My World" which they wrote. A year later, in 1982, the group brought along their teenage brother [[James DeBarge|James]], and shortened their name to just '''DeBarge'''. That year, they released their second album, ''[[All This Love (album)|All This Love]]'', with which the siblings found musical success, particularly with "[[I Like It (DeBarge song)|I Like It]]", for which Bunny wrote parts of the lyrics, alongside her brothers Randy and El. The group followed up this success with their third album, ''[[In A Special Way]]'', in 1983. The album yielded another hit with Bunny as a lyricist, with the gospel-influenced "[[Time Will Reveal]]". The album also included several more highlights including two more Bunny-composed ballads, "[[Stay with Me (DeBarge song)|Stay with Me]]" and "[[A Dream (DeBarge song)|A Dream]]", the last song Bunny took lead vocals on. Like ''All This Love'' before it, ''In a Special Way'' went gold, paving the way for the group's biggest success in 1985 with the ''[[Rhythm of the Night (album)|Rhythm of the Night]]'' album, with the [[Rhythm of the Night (song)|title track]] becoming a top five crossover hit. However, the album marked the beginning of the end of Bunny's tenure with the group. Pressured to go solo after numerous arguments with her brothers, Bunny followed brother El out of the group in 1986 and the following year, Bunny put out her debut album, ''[[In Love (Bunny DeBarge album)|In Love]]'', releasing one single, "Save the Best for Me". The album failed to deliver any hits or stay on the charts long and Bunny soon left the label. Besieged by a growing drug addiction that had started during her heyday with DeBarge, she quietly exited from the music business at the end of the 1980s and with the exception of projects involving gospel music, including an album featuring some of her brothers, herself and their mother, Bunny hasn't released any more solo work. ===Personal life=== Bunny DeBarge has been married twice. In several of DeBarge's albums, she is listed as Etterlene Jordan and is sometimes referred to as either Etterlene Jordan-Knight or Etterlene DeBarge Knight. Bunny is the mother of four children and a grandmother of fifteen and still lives in Michigan, having moved back to Grand Rapids after years living in California. Much like her brothers, Bunny DeBarge has dealt with drug issues, going back to her teen years, which started with [[marijuana]] and moving up to [[prescription medication]] during her heyday with DeBarge.{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p16916|label=Bunny DeBarge}} It soon escalated to usage of [[cocaine]]. Bunny entered rehab several times to kick her habit. In 2008, she broke her silence issuing her autobiography, ''The Kept Ones'', in which she talked about her father's abuse towards her and her siblings and her dealings with substance abuse.[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0974613665 The Kept Ones] on Amazon.com That year she appeared on the debut episode of the [[TV One (US TV network)|TV One]] series, ''[[Unsung (TV series)|Unsung]]'', in which she talked about her childhood and her time with DeBarge, along with brothers Randy and James. The trio again appeared on TV three years later in September 2011, on the show ''[[Lifechangers]]'' alongside Bunny's daughter Janae. James entered the rehabilitation program but left a few hours later. Randy left a few days later. Bunny entered the rehabilitation program and completed her entire experience. After leaving the rehabilitation program in West Hollywood, California, Bunny has been touring and focusing on her new album.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2011/09/debarge_family_featured_today.html |title=DeBarge family featured today on 'Dr. Drew's Lifechangers' |publisher=MLive.com |date=2011-09-21 |accessdate=2014-04-26}} ==Discography== {{main|DeBarge discography}} ;with DeBarge * ''[[The DeBarges]]'' (1981) * ''[[All This Love (album)|All This Love]]'' (1982) * ''[[In a Special Way]]'' (1983) * ''[[Rhythm of the Night (album)|Rhythm of the Night]]'' (1985) * ''[[Back on Track (DeBarge album)|Back on Track]]'' (1991) ;Solo * ''[[In Love (Bunny DeBarge album)|In Love]]'' (1987) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DeBarge}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Debarge, Bunny}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:DeBarge members]] [[Category:20th-century American singers]] [[Category:American female singer-songwriters]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:American sopranos]] [[Category:Musicians from Grand Rapids, Michigan]] [[Category:American gospel singers]] [[Category:American soul singers]] [[Category:Motown artists]] [[Category:American rhythm and blues singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American people of Native American descent]] [[Category:American female composers]] [[Category:American composers]] [[Category:American Christians]] [[Category:DeBarge family]] [[Category:Songwriters from Michigan]] [[Category:Singers from Detroit]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]]

{{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = | name = | honorific_suffix = | image = Charles Ainsworth Mitchell.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date |1867|11|20}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age |1948|01|05|1867|11|20}} | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}}--> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = | workplaces = | patrons = | education = | alma_mater = | thesis_title = <!--(or | thesis1_title = and | thesis2_title = )--> | thesis_url = <!--(or | thesis1_url = and | thesis2_url = )--> | thesis_year = <!--(or | thesis1_year = and | thesis2_year = )--> | doctoral_advisor = <!--(or | doctoral_advisors = )--> | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = <!--(or | spouses = )--> | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!--{{URL|www.example.com}}--> | footnotes = }} '''Charles Ainsworth Mitchell''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRIC|FCS}} (20 November 1867 – 5 January 1948)<ref name=Cox1948/> was a British chemist and forensic scientist who made a special study of the microscopic and chemical study of handwriting.<ref name="times1907">The Police Courts, The Times (London, England) November 29, 1907, page 6, accessed October 24, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7159501/the_police_courts_the_times_london/</ref> He was a Fellow of the [[Royal Institute of Chemistry]] and the [[Chemical Society]], and member of the Society of [[Public Analysts]]<ref name="times1907"/><ref name="Times1915"/> He was editor of ''[[The Analyst (journal)|The Analyst]]'' for 25 years, president of the Medico-Legal Society (1935–1937), and vice president of the Society of Chemistry (1937–1940).<ref name=Cox1948/>
==Life== Mitchell was born 20 November 1867 in [[Thetford]], England, the third son of Dr. T. H. Mitchell. He was educated at [[King William's College]], and [[Exeter College, Oxford]], graduating in 1889. In 1899 he married Edith Boyle Keely.<ref name=Cox1948>{{cite journal|last1=Cox|first1=H. E.|title=Obituary: Charles Ainsworth Mitchell 1867–1948|journal=[[The Analyst (journal)|The Analyst]]|year=1948|volume=73|issue=863|pages=55–57|doi=10.1039/AN948730055B|bibcode=1948Ana....73...55C}}</ref><ref name=BMJ1948/>
==Career==
===Chemist=== As a chemist and a scientist, Mitchell's work covered a wide range of topics. He became a fellow of the [[Royal Institute of Chemistry]] in 1897 and of the [[Chemical Society]] in 1916.<ref name=Cox1948/><ref name=BMJ1948>{{cite journal|title=C. A. Mitchell, M.A., D.Sc.|journal=[[British Medical Journal]]|volume= 1|number=4541|date=January 17, 1948|pages=128–129|jstor=25362064|doi=10.1136/bmj.1.4541.128}}</ref> In 1907 he advocated using a [[pinhole camera]] to photograph the sun in an article in ''Knowledge and Scientific News'', a method which he notes was known as early as 1615 but seemed to have been forgotten.<ref>Pinhole Pictures, Peninsula Enterprise (Accomac, Virginia) January 4, 1908, page 4, accessed October 24, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7159530/pinhole_pictures_peninsula_enterprise/</ref><ref>Wall, E. J. Pinhole Photography of the Sun, The Photographic News: A Weekly Record of the Progress of Photography, Volume 51, Cassell, Petter and Galpin, 1907 accessed as page 399 of https://books.google.com/books?id=3Ts8AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA399 on October 24, 2016</ref> In 1911, he advocated the switch from lead to copper pipes for drinking water. His reasoning was that copper would better be able to alert the drinker to an excess of poisonous sulphates in the water.<ref>Copper Water Pipes, Duluth News-Tribune (Duluth, Minnesota), Saturday, October 7, 1911, Volume: 43 Issue: 155 Page: 13</ref> In 1920, he became editor of ''[[The Analyst (journal)|The Analyst]]'', a journal of the Chemical Society, and under 25 years of his editorship the journal expanded in scope and increased in reputation.<ref name=Nature1945>{{cite journal|title=Dr. C. Ainsworth Mitchell and ''The Analyst''|journal=Nature|date=13 October 1945|volume=156|issue=3963|pages=443–444|doi=10.1038/156443d0|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v156/n3963/abs/156443d0.html|bibcode=1945Natur.156T.443.}}</ref>
===Criminologist=== In 1911 he was head of the inspection bureau of [[Scotland Yard]].<ref>Expert Testimony, The Rock Island Daily Union (Rock Island, Illinois) October 16, 1911, page 6, accessed October 24, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7159618/expert_testimony_the_rock_island_daily/</ref> He frequently served as an expert witness. In 1915, he gave testimony about the invisible ink used in the case of German spy, Anton Kuepferle.<ref name="Times1915">Alleged Spy on Trial, The Times (London, England) May 19, 1915, page 22, column 4 accessed October 24, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7159685/alleged_spy_on_trial_the_times/</ref>
In 1925 he analyzed documents and seals of [[Mary, Queen of Scots]] and claimed to show that Mary was innocent of conspiracy to assassinate Queen [[Elizabeth I of England]]. He said that [[William Maitland of Lethington|William Maitland]], Mary's secretary, forged Mary's hand in the documents which led to Mary's execution.<ref>Recent Tests Show Mary, Queen of Scots, Innocent, Brown County Democrat (Nashville, Indiana) June 23, 1925, page 4, accessed October 24, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7159730//</ref> In 1929, he was an advocate of the use of [[fingerprints]] to determine identity, a method which he traced to [[Sir William Herschel, 2nd Baronet|Sir William Herschell]] in 1853, who saw the method used in to document an individuals identity in [[India]], where he was a commissioner.<ref>The Use of Finger Prints, The Age (Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, December 14, 1929, page 5, accessed October 24, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7159796/the_use_of_finger_prints_the_age/</ref> He showed that monkeys may be identified by fingerprints and that the same could be done with the markings on a cow's nose.<ref>Monkey's identified, Lincoln Evening Journal (Lincoln, Nebraska), November 22, 1929, page 13, accessed October 24, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7159753/monkeys_identified_lincoln_evening/</ref>
He was hired by [[Ruth White (Bahá'í author)|Ruth White]] to analyze the ''[[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá]]''. White opposed parts of the will that suggested the establishment of a hierarchy in the [[Bahá'í Faith]]. His report concluded in agreement with White, that the document was a forgery.<ref>Momen, Moojan. Studies in Honor of the Late Hasan M. Balyuzi. Vol. 5. Kalimát Press, 1988. p273-274</ref> White placed Mitchell's signed report on the writing shown on the photographs of the document with the U.S. [[Library of Congress]] in 1930.{{clarify|date=July 2016}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fglaysher.com/bahaicensorship/CAMitchell_Report.htm|title=Dr. C. (Charles) Ainsworth Mitchell, Report on the Writing Shown on the Photographs of the Alleged Will of Abdu'l-Baha, Library of Congress, 1930, Ruth White|first=|last=Bahais|publisher=}}{{Better source|date=October 2016}}</ref>

'''Charley R. Lockhart''' (August 1876 - 1954) was Texas State Treasurer from 1931 - 1941. He was the shortest Texas elected official at 3'9" (114 cm) tall.
==Early life== Lockhart born in [[Dallas County, Texas]] in August 1876 to John C. R. and Lucretia Lockhart. They moved to [[Snyder, Texas]] in 1898.
==Career== Lockhart was elected [[Scurry County, Texas|Scurry County]] treasurer in 1900. He was re-elected to the county office eight times. In 1919 he went to Austin to work with the [[sergeant-at-arms]] of the [[Texas House of Representatives]].
In 1930 he was elected state treasurer. In 1931, ''Ripley's Believe It Or Not'' featured a drawing of Lockhart under the caption "Texas, the largest state in the Union, has the smallest treasurer, Charley Lockhart, 45 inches tall." The ''[[Houston Post]]'' interviewed Lockhart when he entered the race for the state treasurer's office, and he is quoted as saying, "I want you to make it perfectly clear that I am fighting this battle on manhood alone," he said. "I don't want the votes that are given me through a feeling that life has not handed me a square deal. Life has been good to me. I have filled public office, earned the confidence and friendship of my fellows and educated my children. . . . I'm simply a little man with big ideas and sufficient experience and ability to carry my ideas out..."<ref>[http://www.snydertex.com/history/cemetery.htm Historic Snyder Cemetery|] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090717233828/http://www.snydertex.com/history/cemetery.htm |date=July 17, 2009 }}</ref>
He resigned his office on October 24, 1941 and was replaced by his hand-picked Deputy [[Jesse James (Texas Treasurer)|Jesse James]].
==Death and interment== Lockhart died in 1954 and was buried in the Snyder Cemetery.
==Other media== * A newsreel showing the swearing-in of Lockhart is available [http://www.thoughtequity.com/video/clip/331777_060.do]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Choirul Huda | image = Choirul_Huda.png | fullname = Choirul Huda | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1979|6|2}} | birth_place = [[Lamongan Regency|Lamongan]], [[Indonesia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|10|15|1979|06|02|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Lamongan Regency|Lamongan]], [[Indonesia]] | height = {{height|m=1.83}} | currentclub = | clubnumber = | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Persela Lamongan]] | years1 = 1999–2017 | clubs1 = [[Persela Lamongan]] | caps1 = 503 | goals1 = 0 | totalcaps = 503 | totalgoals = 0 | pcupdate = 15 October 2017 }} '''Choirul Huda''' (2 June 1979 – 15 October 2017<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bola.com/indonesia/read/3129214/kapten-persela-choirul-huda-meninggal-dunia|title=Kapten Persela Choirul Huda Meninggal Dunia|last=Bola.com|work=bola.com|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref>) was an [[Indonesia]]n professional [[Association football|footballer]] and [[Civil service|civil servant]].
==Personal life== Huda began his career in [[Persela Lamongan]] since 1999 and stayed with the club until his death in 2017<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rappler.com/indonesia/olahraga/185384-profil-hal-choirul-huda-persela|title=5 hal tentang kiper Persela Lamongan Choirul Huda|work=Rappler|access-date=15 October 2017|language=id}}</ref>. He was dubbed '''''"The One Man, One Club, One Love"''''', and became a ''Legend'' for [[Persela Lamongan]].
Indonesian football writer Antony Sutton met Huda a few months ago while researching a book before his death described him as :
''"He played for his local team, he was living the dream,". "He was just happy in his skin and happy in his town."''
''"He's a legend - a one-club man, His ambition was to become his club's goalkeeping coach after he retired."''
''"He never created a fuss about anything. He loved what he was doing but did it in such an understated way."''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41630244|title=Choirul Huda: Indonesian goalkeeper dies after collision with team-mate|date=15 October 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
He was married and had two children.
== International career == Huda was given his first call-up for a [[2015 AFC Asian Cup qualification]] in 1-1 draw against [[China national football team|China]] on 15 October 2013. Huda was called-up seven times for [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]] in his national career but he received no single caps.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.viva.co.id/bola/bola-nasional/967377-choirul-huda-sempat-7-kali-dipanggil-timnas-indonesia|title=Choirul Huda Sempat 7 Kali Dipanggil Timnas Indonesia - VIVA.co.id|first=PT. VIVA MEDIA BARU -|last=VIVA.co.id|date=16 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
==Death== Huda died after an incident in the match against [[Semen Padang F.C.|Semen Padang]] at [[2017 Liga 1]]. He collided with a teammate, [[Ramon Rodrigues De Mesquita|Ramon Rodrigues]], while trying to collect the ball from an opponent and was struck in the chest. Paramedics immediately gave him sideline emergency treatment. A paramedic said that after the incident, he was still conscious and complained of a chest pain, but his condition soon relapsed and he later died from his injuries in a local hospital.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legendary Indonesian goalkeeper Choirul Huda, 38, dies after tragic collision with team-mate during match|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4982276/Keeper-Choirul-Huda-dies-collision-team-mate.html|website=Daily Mail|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref>
According to a doctor in the local hospital, he suffered a collision on his chest and lower jaw, which caused [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] that ultimately led to his death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indonesian goalkeeper dies after collision with teammate |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/indonesian-goalkeeper-dies-after-collision-with-teammate-9313258|website=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref> Moreover, due to severe injury, he might also have experienced trauma to his head, neck, and chest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Penjelasan Dokter RSUD dr Soegiri soal Meninggalnya Choirul Huda (Indonesian)|url=http://bola.kompas.com/read/2017/10/15/20203948/penjelasan-dokter-rsud-dr-soegiri-soal-meninggalnya-choirul-huda|website=Kompas.com|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref>
==Honours==

([[Latin]] for "With God's Help") |orders = [[Order of Saint-Charles]] |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''coat of arms of Monaco''' refers to the [[arms of dominion]] of the [[Sovereign Prince of Monaco]] in right of [[Monaco]]. ==Shield== The shield is [[blazon]]ed (described in the technical language of [[heraldry]]) as ''fusily'' (or ''[[lozenge (heraldry)|lozengy]]'') ''argent'' and ''gules''. ==Supporters== The monks supporting the shield in the coat of arms allude to the conquest of Monaco in 1297, when [[François Grimaldi]] entered the city with soldiers dressed as monks, with swords hidden under their cassocks. ==Collar== The collar surrounding the shield represents the [[Order of Saint-Charles]]. ==Motto== The Grimaldi family's motto, ''Deo Juvante'', is [[Latin]] for "With God's Help". ==References== * {{cite web|author=Velde, François |title=Monaco |work=Heraldica |url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/national/monaco.htm | accessdate=March 25, 2005 }} {{Monaco topics}} {{Coats of arms of Europe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coat Of Arms Of Monaco}} [[Category:National symbols of Monaco]] [[Category:National coats of arms|Monaco]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crowns|Monaco]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crosses|Monaco]] [[Category:Coats of arms with swords|Monaco]] [[Category:Royal arms of European monarchs|Monaco]] {{monaco-stub}} {{heraldry-stub}}

'''Daryl Keith Holton''' (November 23, 1961 – September 12, 2007)<ref>{{cite web|title=Daryl Keith Holton|work=Clark County Prosecuting Attorney|url=http://www.clarkprosecutor.org/html/death/US/holton1097.htm|accessdate=2007-11-05}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] Gulf War veteran and convicted child killer, executed by [[electric chair|electrocution]] by the state of [[Tennessee]] on September 12, 2007 in [[Riverbend Maximum Security Institution]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]].
== Crime ==
Holton, a [[Gulf War]] Veteran, was 36 years old when he shot his three young sons and their half-sister (Stephen Edward Holton (12), Brent Holton (10), Eric Holton (6), and Kayla Marie Holton (4)) with a Chinese-made semi-automatic rifle on November 30, 1997, at the garage where he worked in [[Shelbyville, Tennessee]]. Holton was divorced, and his ex-wife had custody of the children. About an hour later, Holton turned himself in to the Shelbyville police; he told investigators that he had killed the children because "families should stay together; a father should be with his children." He said he had also planned to kill his ex-wife and then himself, but had changed his mind.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.wbir.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=49000|title=WBIR.com - Knoxville, TN - Convicted child killer Daryl Holton dies in Tenn. electric chair<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="IHT">{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/09/10/america/NA-GEN-US-Death-Penalty-Electrocution.php|title=Tennessee plans for first electrocution in nearly 47 years|accessdate=2007-11-21|publisher=International Herald Tribune|date=2007-09-10|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
== Trial ==
At his June 1999 trial, Holton declined to testify on his own behalf, although his attorney sought to convince the jury that Holton was mentally incompetent at the time of the killings. Witnesses for the defense testified that Holton showed signs of [[carbon monoxide poisoning]], although they could not definitively conclude that he had been exposed to carbon monoxide. Psychiatrists for the state and the defense also testified that Holton had [[major depressive disorder]] and [[passive-aggressive personality disorder]] at the time of the murders. The jury rejected the insanity defense; Holton was found guilty and sentenced to death.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/tn-supreme-court/1476832.html|title=FindLaw's Supreme Court of Tennessee case and opinions.|website=Findlaw}}</ref>
During his imprisonment, Holton became an amateur legal expert, and he took steps to ignore the automatic and voluntary appeals process afforded to all condemned men and women under state and U.S. law. He also declined to cooperate with the federally or state-appointed capital defenders who sought to offer him legal assistance and counsel. For this reason, he is often included among the group described as death row "volunteers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deathpenaltyinfo.org/article.php?did=1666|title=DPIC - Death Penalty Information Center|website=www.deathpenaltyinfo.org}}</ref>
==Execution== Holton chose to die in the [[electric chair]], rather than by [[lethal injection]], which is now the standard method of execution in Tennessee. Death-row inmates who committed their capital crime when the electric chair was still the official execution method are permitted to choose between the two methods.<ref name="IHT" /> Holton was the first person to be executed by electrocution in Tennessee in 47 years. Moments before his execution, prison warden Ricky Bell asked Holton if he had any final words. He replied: "Two words: I do".<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>{{cite news|last=Raybin|first=David |title=Lawyer for the Condemned: I Witnessed What Should be the Last Electric Chair Execution|url=http://www.hollinslegal.com/2014/06/23/the-last-electric-chair-execution/|publisher=Hollins, Raybin & Weissman, LLC|accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref> He decided against the traditional special last meal before his execution and instead, ate the regular prison meal which consisted of riblets on a bun, mixed vegetables, baked beans, white cake with white icing and iced tea.
Holton's was the fourth execution in Tennessee since 2000 and first by the electric chair since 1960 (the last Pre-[[Furman v. Georgia|Furman]] execution). It was also the first use of Tennessee's electric chair after it was retrofitted by [[Fred A. Leuchter]] and moved to Riverbend from the former [[Tennessee State Prison]]. Holton was the third [[death row]] inmate executed under administration of [[Governor of Tennessee|Governor]] [[Phil Bredesen]]. He was also the first American put to death by electrocution since July 20, 2006. The last was [[Brandon Wayne Hedrick]] in [[Virginia]], who also chose electrocution over injection. His dead body was cremated after his execution. A [https://www.nashvilletnlaw.com/blog/the-last-electric-chair-execution/ first hand account] of the execution was documented by Holton's attorney, David Raybin.
== Controversy ==
His case raised some controversy because of rumors about his history of mental illness.<ref>[http://www.tcask.org/cases/holton/holton.html ]{{dead link|date=November 2018}}</ref> While execution of the mentally retarded was prohibited by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] case ''[[Atkins v. Virginia]]'' of 2002, the execution of the mentally ill has never been held to be in violation of the [[Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Eighth Amendment]].{{clarify|reason=Atkins v. Virginia appears to exactly say it's in violation of the Eighth Amendment|date=August 2013}}
Holton, his motives, and the ethics of his execution are examined in the documentary film ''[[Robert Blecker Wants Me Dead]]''.
== See also ==
